awd_titl_txt: INT: Project Learning with Automated, Networked Supports (PLANS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Learning with Automated, Networked Supports (PLANS) will contribute to science and engineering education in middle schools.  This software technology will support deep learning as students carry out project-based work.  Specifically, PLANS will connect tools for brainstorming, planning, modeling, sketching, data gathering, graphing, designing, and testing, with technology that automatically assesses use of the tools and generates guidance that supports learning.  This project is funded by the Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies program, which integrates opportunities offered by emerging technologies with advances in what is known about how people learn.

PLANS will define a genre of technology-enabled learning resources that combine investigation tools within a sequence of student-led projects, and analytics technologies that guide students toward deeper understanding. The researchers will explore an instance of this genre applied to middle school physical science with a focus on energy content, science and engineering practices, and cross cutting themes. By implementing and researching a half-semester sequence of projects, the researchers will examine synergies between investigation and analytic technologies that result in substantial learning gains. The researchers will collaborate with five middle schools serving diverse student populations. Through three iterations of improvements in the technologies and project materials, the project will optimize and document the educational value of this approach.

por.por_cntn:
Project Learning with Automated, Networked Supports (PLANS) was a four-year INT Cyberlearning proposal. PLANS explored how investigation tools and analytic technologies can support students to develop coherent understanding of science and engineering through student-led design projects that incorporate opportunities for student choice. PLANS projects build student ability to design their own investigations, while also increasing understanding of core disciplinary concepts and cross-cutting themes in physical science and engineering as specified by the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). PLANS developed and studied how students benefit from investigation technologies such as computational models, probeware, graphing tools, drawing tools, critique activities, and the student notebook. These technologies enhanced student ability to plan and complete sophisticated science and engineering design projects. To guide student investigations, PLANS developed analytic technologies to automatically score student work and diagnose student progress. The diagnostic information is used to provide automated, adaptive guidance for students and to inform teachers of student progress.  

Contributions to Intellectual Merit. PLANS advanced our understanding of ways to support students to integrate understanding gained from hands-on activities and online computational models and to design their own investigations. We iteratively refined five web-based units that included hands-on activities to strengthen student learning of both science and engineering concepts. Developed units include Self-Propelled Vehicles (Scooters, Figure 1), Solar Ovens (Figures 2a and 2b), Global Climate Change: Climate Action Plan (Figure 3), Musical Instruments, and Chemical Reactions and Alternative Fuels [https://wise.berkeley.edu]. These five units are aligned with NGSS science and engineering performance expectations. They incorporate the investigation tools and analytic technologies. Individual research studies for each unit demonstrated the positive impacts of the curriculum units and tools on student learning. Furthermore, PLANS research identified design patterns for combining hands-on design projects with interactive computational models to engage students in developing their own science investigations. 

Integrating science and design knowledge. Studies found that interleaving the learning of scientific concepts, with designing and building a solution, led to greater science-design knowledge integration than sequencing all the scientific concepts before moving on to the design task. Integrating engineering and science instruction also led to more effective student experimentation with the computer model. Students ran more complete trials and more informative trials when using a computer model to test their many design conjectures, compared to when learning science first and then using the computer model to test their planned design. Using the model to plan their design was more generative for science learning, than using the model to reflect on their final design.  

Student choice. PLANS contributed to our understanding of the motivational and intellectual value of supporting students to choose their own investigations. For example, students who choose their activity, compared to those who are randomly assigned to a topic to investigate gain better insights and report greater interest in science. The benefits of student choice are mediated by teacher implementation. When teachers encouraged and supported students to make a choice based on their personal curiosity, choice had a greater impact on learning. 

Analytics. PLANS contributed knowledge to strengthen use of  Natural Language Processing (NLP) models to automatically score students? level of science-engineering knowledge integration. These scores have accuracy equivalent to those of  human coders. PLANS showed that the design of activities using NLP was important. Activities that used the NLP derived score to promote knowledge integration were more effective than automated specific guidance that pointed out a specific incorrect idea. Further, automated knowledge integration scoring and guidance can alert the teacher to students in need of assistance in real-time, and provide teachers an adaptive hint to guide students? learning. Coupling automated and teacher guidance was more effective for struggling students than providing multiple rounds of adaptive, automated guidance, as teachers further personalized the guidance to students' emerging ideas.

Contributions to Broader Impacts. PLANS broadened the impact of science instruction by developing curricular materials that focused on personally relevant socio-scientific issues. These units increased student interest in science by helping learners to make connections between science and their everyday experiences. Results showed the impact of these units on students from non-dominant cultures in participating schools. PLANS is committed to broad dissemination and implementation of its research, curriculum designs, assessments, and technologies through papers, talks, and the Web-based Inquiry Science Environment (WISE) website. 

All PLANS units are freely available for use as-is, and customizable with WISE?s authoring tools. Free, open-source platforms like WISE, which already serves over 20,000 teachers worldwide, are sustainable by virtue of offering an integrated collection of carefully designed interactive multimedia-rich activities, assessments, student investigation and collaboration tools, and teacher supports.
